title: Astros’ Gerrit Cole, superhuman for five months, finally looks mortal in Game 1
text:
The 2019 World Series: What you need to read

The Washington Nationals won their first World Series game in franchise history and took a 1-0 series lead over the Houston Astros in the best-of-seven series. The Nationals won, 5-4, in Houston.

How it happened for Washington: Juan Soto, a generational talent well-known to Washington fans, took center stage Tuesday night. The 20-year-old star hit a game-tying home run in the fourth inning and batted in the game-winning run in the fifth.

What went wrong for Houston: Gerrit Cole, the Astros’ ace who had not lost a game since July, looked mortal in Game 1 — allowing five earned runs, the most he’d ever allowed in a postseason game.

Up next: Game 2 is in Houston on Wednesday at 8:07 p.m. Eastern. Stephen Strasburg will start for the Nationals opposite Justin Verlander for the Astros.

Catch up on what you’ve missed:

• What’s the deal with the Nationals and “Baby Shark"?

• World Series schedule and how to watch

• The bandwagon fan’s guide to the Nationals

• Washington baseball history: From the Senators to the Nationals
description: Cole entered this Game 1 of the World Series with a run of 19 straight winning decisions, the longest streak of any pitcher in a year since Rube Marquard in 1912.
